revision.text:
The '''just-world hypothesis''' or '''just-world fallacy''' is the [[cognitive bias]] (or assumption) that a person's actions are inherently inclined to bring [[morality|morally]] [[justice|fair]] and fitting consequences to that person, to the end of all noble actions being eventually rewarded and all evil actions eventually punished. In other words, the just-world hypothesis is the tendency to attribute consequences to—or expect consequences as the result of—a universal force that restores moral balance. This belief generally implies the existence of cosmic [[justice]], [[destiny]], [[divine providence]], [[desert (philosophy)|desert]], [[Balance (metaphysics)|stability]], or [[cosmos|order]], and has high potential to result in [[informal fallacy|fallacy]], especially when used to [[Rationalization (making excuses)|rationalize]] people's misfortune on the grounds that they "deserve" it.
The hypothesis popularly appears in the [[English language]] in various [[figures of speech]] that imply guaranteed negative reprisal, such as: "[[wikt:get what's coming to one|you got what was coming to you]]", "[[wikt:what goes around comes around|what goes around comes around]]", "[[wikt:chickens come home to roost|chickens come home to roost]]", "everything happens for a reason", and "[[wikt:reap what one sows|you reap what you sow]]". This hypothesis has been widely studied by [[social psychology|social psychologists]] since [[Melvin J. Lerner]] conducted seminal work on the belief in a just world in the early 1960s.<ref name="An Overview">Lerner, M.J. & Montada, L. (1998). An Overview: Advances in Belief in a Just World Theory and Methods, in Leo Montada & M.J. Lerner (Eds.). ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=SeiPBAAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage Responses to Victimizations and Belief in a Just World]'' (1–7). Plenum Press: New York.</ref> Research has continued since then, examining the predictive capacity of the hypothesis in various situations and across cultures, and clarifying and expanding the theoretical understandings of just-world beliefs.<ref name="Furnham2003Decade">Furnham, A. (2003). [https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0191886902000727 Belief in a just world: research progress over the past decade]. ''Personality and Individual Differences''; 34: 795–817.</ref>
==Emergence== Many philosophers and social theorists have observed and considered the phenomenon of belief in a just world, going back to at least as early as the [[Pyrrhonism|Pyrrhonist]] philosopher [[Sextus Empiricus]] writing around 180 CE who argued against this belief.<ref>Sextus Empiricus, "Outlines of Pyrrhonism", Book 1, Chapter 13, Section 32</ref> Lerner's work made the just-world hypothesis a focus of research in the field of social psychology.
===Melvin Lerner=== Lerner was prompted to study [[justice]] beliefs and the just-world hypothesis in the context of social psychological inquiry into negative social and societal interactions.<ref name="MontadaLernerPreface">Montada, L. & Lerner, M.J. (1998). Preface, in Leo Montada & M.J. Lerner (Eds.). ''Responses to Victimizations and Belief in a Just World'' (pp. vii–viii). Plenum Press: New York.</ref> Lerner saw his work as extending [[Stanley Milgram]]'s [[Milgram experiments|work on obedience]]. He sought to answer the questions of how regimes that cause cruelty and suffering maintain popular support, and how people come to accept [[social norms]] and laws that produce misery and suffering.<ref name="LernerSimmonsObserver">{{cite journal |last=Lerner |first=M. |last2=Simmons |first2=C. H. |year=1966 |title=Observer's Reaction to the 'Innocent Victim': Compassion or Rejection? |journal=Journal of Personality and Social Psychology |volume=4 |issue=2 |pages=203–210 |doi=10.1037/h0023562 |pmid=5969146 |url=http://web.mit.edu/curhan/www/docs/Articles/biases/4_J_Personality_Social_Psychology_203_(Lerner).pdf}}</ref>
Lerner's inquiry was influenced by repeatedly witnessing the tendency of observers to [[victim blaming|blame victims]] for their suffering. During his clinical training as a psychologist, he observed treatment of mentally ill persons by the health care practitioners with whom he worked. Although he knew them to be kindhearted, educated people, they often blamed patients for the patients' own suffering.<ref name="LernerFundamental">Lerner (1980). ''The Belief in a Just World: A Fundamental Delusion''. Plenum: New York.</ref> Lerner also describes his surprise at hearing his students [[wikt:derogate|derogate]] (disparage, belittle) the poor, seemingly oblivious to the [[structural violence|structural forces]] that contribute to poverty.<ref name="MontadaLernerPreface" /> In a study on rewards, he observed that when one of two men was chosen at random to receive a reward for a task, that caused him to be more favorably evaluated by observers, even when the observers had been informed that the recipient of the reward was chosen at random.<ref name="LernerMillerLooking">Lerner, M. J., & Miller, D. T. (1978). [http://psycnet.apa.org/record/1979-26009-001 Just world research and the attribution process: Looking back and ahead]. ''Psychological Bulletin'', 85(5), 1030–1051</ref><ref name="MaesEightStages" /> Existing social psychological theories, including [[cognitive dissonance]], could not fully explain these phenomena.<ref name="MaesEightStages">Maes, J. (1998) [https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-1-4757-6418-5_10 Eight Stages in the Development of Research on the Construct of BJW?], in Leo Montada & M.J. Lerner (Eds.). ''Responses to Victimizations and Belief in a Just World'' (pp. 163–185). Plenum Press: New York.</ref> The desire to understand the processes that caused these phenomena led Lerner to conduct his first experiments on what is now called the just-world hypothesis.
==Early evidence== In 1966, Lerner and his colleagues began a series of experiments that used shock paradigms to investigate observer responses to [[victimization]]. In the first of these experiments conducted at the [[University of Kansas]], 72 female subjects were made to watch a confederate receiving electrical shocks under a variety of conditions. Initially, subjects were upset by observing the apparent suffering. But as the suffering continued and observers remained unable to intervene, the observers began to derogate the victim. Derogation was greater when the observed suffering was greater. But when subjects were told the victim would receive compensation for her suffering, subjects did not derogate the victim.<ref name="LernerSimmonsObserver" /> Lerner and colleagues replicated these findings in subsequent studies, as did other researchers.<ref name="LernerMillerLooking" />
==Theory== To explain these studies' findings, Lerner theorized that there was a prevalent belief in a just world. A just world is one in which actions and conditions have predictable, appropriate consequences. These actions and conditions are typically individuals' behaviors or attributes. The specific conditions that correspond to certain consequences are socially determined by a society's norms and ideologies. Lerner presents the belief in a just world as functional: it maintains the idea that one can influence the world in a predictable way. Belief in a just world functions as a sort of "contract" with the world regarding the consequences of behavior. This allows people to plan for the future and engage in effective, goal-driven behavior. Lerner summarized his findings and his theoretical work in his 1980 monograph ''The Belief in a Just World: A Fundamental Delusion''.<ref name="LernerFundamental" />
Lerner hypothesized that the belief in a just world is crucially important for people to maintain for their own well-being. But people are confronted daily with evidence that the world is not just: people suffer without apparent cause. Lerner explained that people use strategies to eliminate threats to their belief in a just world. These strategies can be [[Rationality|rational]] or irrational. Rational strategies include accepting the reality of injustice, trying to prevent injustice or provide restitution, and accepting one's own limitations. Non-rational strategies include [[denial]], [[Social withdrawal|withdrawal]], and [[Rationalization (making excuses)|reinterpretation]] of the event.{{citation needed|date = December 2011}}
There are a few modes of reinterpretation that could make an event fit the belief in a just world. One can reinterpret the outcome, the cause, and/or the character of the victim. In the case of observing the injustice of the suffering of innocent people, one major way to rearrange the cognition of an event is to interpret the victim of suffering as deserving.<ref name="An Overview" /> Specifically, observers can blame victims for their suffering on the basis of their behaviors and/or their characteristics.<ref name="LernerMillerLooking" /> Much psychological research on the belief in a just world has focused on these negative social phenomena of [[victim blaming]] and victim derogation in [[#Additional evidence|different contexts]].<ref name="Furnham2003Decade" />
An additional effect of this thinking is that individuals experience less personal [[vulnerability]] because they do not believe they have done anything to deserve or cause negative outcomes.<ref name="Furnham2003Decade" /> This is related to the [[self-serving bias]] observed by social psychologists.<ref>Linden, M. & Maercker, A. (2011) ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=FCdQlTzL-aUC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage Embitterment: Societal, psychological, and clinical perspectives].'' Wien: Springer.</ref>
Many researchers have interpreted just-world beliefs as an example of [[causal attribution]]. In victim blaming, the causes of victimization are attributed to an individual rather than to a situation. Thus, the consequences of belief in a just world may be related to or explained in terms of particular patterns of causal attribution.<ref>Howard, J. (1984). [http://psycnet.apa.org/record/1985-04021-001 Societal influences on attribution: Blaming some victims more than others]. ''Journal of Personality and Social Psychology'', 47(3), 494–505.</ref>
==Alternatives==
===Veridical judgment=== {{See also|Veridicality}} Others have suggested alternative explanations for the derogation of victims. One suggestion is that derogation effects are based on accurate judgments of a victim's character. In particular, in relation to Lerner's first studies, some have hypothesized that it would be logical for observers to derogate an individual who would allow himself to be shocked without reason.<ref>Godfrey, B. & Lowe, C. (1975). [http://psycnet.apa.org/record/1975-26823-001 Devaluation of innocent victims: An attribution analysis within the just world paradigm]. ''Journal of Personality and Social Psychology'', 31, 944–951.</ref> A subsequent study by Lerner challenged this alternative hypothesis by showing that individuals are only derogated when they actually suffer; individuals who agreed to undergo suffering but did not were viewed positively.<ref>Lerner, M.J. (1970). The desire for justice and reactions to victims. In J. Macaulay & L. Berkowitz (Eds.), ''Altruism and helping behavior'' (pp. 205–229). New York: Academic Press.</ref>
===Guilt reduction=== Another alternative explanation offered for the derogation of victims early in the development of the just-world hypothesis was that observers derogate victims to reduce their own feelings of [[guilt (emotion)|guilt]]. Observers may feel [[Moral responsibility|responsible]], or guilty, for a victim's suffering if they themselves are involved in the situation or experiment. In order to reduce the guilt, they may devalue the victim.<ref>Davis, K. & Jones, E. (1960). [https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Keith_Davis3/publication/9847296_Changes_in_Interpersonal_Perception_as_a_Means_of_Reducing_Cognitive_Dissonance/links/00b7d519bfb9563e9e000000.pdf Changes in interpersonal perception as a means of reducing cognitive dissonance]. ''Journal of Abnormal and Social Psychology'', 61, 402–410.</ref><ref>Glass, D. (1964). [https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1111/j.1467-6494.1964.tb01357.x Changes in liking as a means of reducing cognitive discrepancies between self-esteem and aggression]. ''Journal of Personality'', 1964, 32, 531–549.</ref><ref>Cialdini, R. B., Kenrick, D. T., & Hoerig, J. H. (1976). [http://psycnet.apa.org/record/1976-26028-001 Victim derogation in the Lerner paradigm: Just world or just justification?] ''Journal of Personality and Social Psychology'', 33(6), 719–724.</ref> Lerner and colleagues claim that there has not been adequate evidence to support this interpretation. They conducted one study that found derogation of victims occurred even by observers who were not implicated in the process of the experiment and thus had no reason to feel guilty.<ref name="LernerMillerLooking" />
===Discomfort reduction===
Alternatively, victim derogation and other strategies may only be ways to alleviate discomfort after viewing suffering. This would mean that the primary motivation is not to restore a belief in a just world, but to reduce discomfort caused by [[empathy|empathizing]]. Studies have shown that victim derogation does not suppress subsequent helping activity and that empathizing with the victim plays a large role when assigning blame. According to [[Ervin Staub]],<ref>{{cite book|last1=Staub|first1=Ervin|title=Positive Social Behavior and Morality: Social and Personal Influences, Volume 1|date=1978|publisher=Academic Press Inc.|isbn=978-0-12-663101-2|pages=169–170|url=https://books.google.com/?id=GiOLBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA169&lpg=PA169&q=reduce%20discomfort%20suffering%20erwin%20just%20world|accessdate=12 March 2015}}</ref> devaluing the victim should lead to lesser compensation if restoring belief in a just world was the primary motive; instead, there is virtually no difference in compensation amounts whether the compensation precedes or follows devaluation. [[Psychopathy]] has been linked to the lack of just-world maintaining strategies, possibly due to dampened emotional reactions and lack of empathy.<ref name="Hafer2005">{{cite journal|last1=Hafer |first1=Carolyn L. |last2=Bègue |first2=Laurent |last3=Choma |first3=Becky L. |last4=Dempsey |first4=Julie L. |title=Belief in a Just World and Commitment to Long-Term Deserved Outcomes |journal=Social Justice Research |date=2005 |volume=18 |issue=4 |pages=429–444 |doi=10.1007/s11211-005-8569-3 |url=http://www.lps.univ-savoie.fr/uploads/PDF/576.pdf |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131228091123/http://www.lps.univ-savoie.fr/uploads/PDF/576.pdf |archivedate=2013-12-28 |df= |citeseerx=10.1.1.507.4227 }}</ref>
==Additional evidence== After Lerner's first studies, other researchers replicated these findings in other settings in which individuals are victimized. This work, which began in the 1970s and continues today, has investigated how observers react to victims of random calamities like traffic accidents, as well as rape and [[domestic violence]], illnesses, and poverty.<ref name="An Overview" /> Generally, researchers have found that observers of the suffering of innocent victims tend to both derogate and blame victims for their suffering. Observers thus maintain their belief in a just world by changing their cognitions about the victims' character.<ref>Reichle, B., Schneider, A., & Montada, L. (1998). [https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-1-4757-6418-5_4 How do observers of victimization preserve their belief in a just world cognitively or actionally?] In L. Montada & M. J. Lerner (Eds.), ''Responses to victimizations and belief in a just world'' (pp. 55–86). New York: Plenum.</ref>
In the early 1970s, social psychologists [[Zick Rubin]] and Letitia Anne Peplau developed a measure of belief in a just world.<ref>Rubin, Z. & Peplau, A. (1973). [https://spssi.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1111/j.1540-4560.1973.tb00104.x Belief in a just world and reactions to another's lot: A study of participants in the national draft lottery]. ''Journal of Social Issues'', 29, 73–93.</ref> This measure and its revised form published in 1975 allowed for the study of individual differences in just-world beliefs.<ref name = "RubinPeplau1975">Rubin, Z. & Peplau, L.A. (1975). [https://web.archive.org/web/20110720073011/http://www.peplaulab.ucla.edu/Publications_files/Rubin%20%26%20Peplau%201975s.pdf Who believes in a just world?] ''Journal of Social Issues'', 31, 65–89.</ref> Much of the subsequent research on the just-world hypothesis used these [[psychometrics|measurement scales]].
===Violence=== Researchers have looked at how observers react to victims of [[rape]] and other [[violence]]. In a formative experiment on rape and belief in a just world by Linda Carli and colleagues, researchers gave two groups of subjects a narrative about interactions between a man and a woman. The description of the interaction was the same until the end; one group received a narrative that had a neutral ending and the other group received a narrative that ended with the man raping the woman. Subjects judged the rape ending as inevitable and blamed the woman in the narrative for the rape on the basis of her behavior, but not her characteristics.<ref>Janoff-Bulman, R., Timko, C., & Carli, L. L. (1985). [https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Christine_Timko/publication/223081344_Cognitive_biases_in_blaming_the_victim/links/59dd3d88aca272b698e141ab/Cognitive-biases-in-blaming-the-victim.pdf Cognitive biases in blaming the victim]. ''Journal of Experimental Social Psychology'', 21(2), 161–177.</ref> These findings have been replicated repeatedly, including using a rape ending and a 'happy ending' (a marriage proposal).<ref name="Furnham2003Decade" /><ref>Carli, L. L. (1999). [http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.830.8628&rep=rep1&type=pdf Cognitive Reconstruction, Hindsight, and Reactions to Victims and Perpetrators]. ''Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin'', 25(8), 966–979.</ref>
Other researchers have found a similar phenomenon for judgments of [[domestic violence|battered partners]]. One study found that observers' labels of blame of female victims of relationship violence increase with the intimacy of the relationship. Observers blamed the perpetrator only in the most significant case of violence, in which a male struck an acquaintance.<ref>Summers, G., & Feldman, N. S. (1984). [http://guilfordjournals.com/doi/abs/10.1521/jscp.1984.2.4.339 Blaming the victim versus blaming the perpetrator:An attributional analysis of spouse abuse]. ''Symposium A Quarterly Journal In Modern Foreign Literatures'', 2(4), 339–347.</ref>
===Bullying=== Researchers have employed the just-world hypothesis to understand [[bullying]]. Given other research on beliefs in a just world, it would be expected that observers would derogate and blame bullying victims, but the opposite has been found: individuals high in just-world belief have stronger anti-bullying [[Attitude (psychology)|attitudes]].<ref>Fox, C. L., Elder, T., Gater, J., & Johnson, E. (2010). [https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1348/000709909X479105 The association between adolescents' beliefs in a just world and their attitudes to victims of bullying]. ''The British journal of educational psychology'', 80(Pt 2), 183–98.</ref> Other researchers have found that strong belief in a just world is associated with lower levels of bullying behavior.<ref>Correia, I., & Dalbert, C. (2008). School Bullying. ''European Psychologist'', 13(4), 248254.</ref> This finding is in keeping with Lerner's understanding of belief in a just world as functioning as a "contract" that governs behavior.<ref name="LernerFundamental" /> There is additional evidence that belief in a just world is protective of the well-being of children and adolescents in the school environment,<ref>Correia, I., Kamble, S. V., & Dalbert, C. (2009). [https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/10615800902729242 Belief in a just world and well-being of bullies, victims and defenders: a study with Portuguese and Indian students]. Anxiety, stress, and coping, 22(5), 497–508.</ref> as has been shown for the [[#Positive health effects|general population]].
===Illness=== Other researchers have found that observers judge sick people as responsible for their illnesses. One experiment showed that persons suffering from a variety of illnesses were derogated on a measure of attractiveness more than healthy individuals were. In comparison to healthy people, victim derogation was found for persons presenting with indigestion, pneumonia, and stomach cancer. Moreover, derogation was found to be higher for those suffering from more severe illnesses, except for those presenting with cancer.<ref>Gruman, J. C., & Sloan, R. P. (1983). [https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1207/s15324834basp0401_4 Disease as Justice: Perceptions of the Victims of Physical Illness]. Basic and Applied Social Psychology, 4(1), 39–46.</ref> Stronger belief in a just world has also been found to correlate with greater derogation of [[AIDS]] victims.<ref name="FurnhamProcterAIDS">Furnham, A. & Procter, E. (1992). [http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/abs/10.1177/001872679204500303 Sphere-specific just world beliefs and attitudes to AIDS]. Human Relations, 45, 265–280.</ref>
===Poverty=== More recently, researchers have explored how people react to [[poverty]] through the lens of the just-world hypothesis. Strong belief in a just world is associated with blaming the poor, with weak belief in a just world associated with identifying external causes of poverty including world economic systems, [[war]], and [[Exploitation of labour|exploitation]].<ref>Harper, D. J., Wagstaff, G. F., Newton, J. T., & Harrison, K. R. (1990). [http://inesad.edu.bo/developmentroast/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/Harper-1990-Poverty-Explanations.pdf Lay causal perceptions of third world poverty and the just world theory]. ''Social Behavior and Personality: an international journal'', 18(2), 235–238. Scientific Journal Publishers.</ref><ref>Harper, D. J., & Manasse, P. R. (1992). [http://psycnet.apa.org/record/1993-29152-001 The Just World and the Third World: British explanations for poverty abroad]. ''The Journal of social psychology'', 6. Heldref Publications.</ref>
===The self as victim=== {{See also|Psychological response to rape|Self blame}} Some research on belief in a just world has examined how people react when they themselves are victimized. An early paper by Dr. Ronnie Janoff-Bulman found that rape victims often blame their own behavior, but not their own characteristics, for their [[victimization]].<ref>Janoff-Bulman, R. (1979). [https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Ronnie_Janoff-Bulman/publication/22629118_Characterological_versus_behavioral_self-blame_Inquiries_into_depression_and_rape/links/54244b5b0cf238c6ea6eac09.pdf Characterological versus behavioral self-blame: inquiries into depression and rape]. ''Journal of Personality and Social Psychology'', 37(10), 1798–809.</ref> It was hypothesized that this may be because blaming one's own behavior makes an event more [[locus of control|controllable]].
These studies on victims of [[#Violence|violence]], [[#Illness|illness]], and [[#Poverty|poverty]] and others like them have provided consistent support for the link between observers' just-world beliefs and their tendency to blame victims for their suffering.<ref name="An Overview" /> As a result, the existence of the just-world hypothesis as a psychological phenomenon has become widely accepted.
==Theoretical refinement== Subsequent work on measuring belief in a just world has focused on identifying multiple dimensions of the belief. This work has resulted in the development of new measures of just-world belief and additional research.<ref name="Furnham2003Decade" /> Hypothesized dimensions of just-world beliefs include belief in an unjust world,<ref>Dalbert, C., Lipkus, I. M., Sallay, H., & Goch, I. (2001). [https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0191886900000556 A just and unjust world: Structure and validity of different world beliefs]. ''Personality and Individual Differences'', 30, 561–577.</ref> beliefs in [[immanent]] [[justice]] and ultimate justice,<ref>Maes, J. (1998). Immanent justice and ultimate justice: two ways of believing in justice. In L. Montada, & M. Lerner (Eds.), ''Responses to victimizations and belief in a just world'' (pp. 9–40). New York: Plenum Press.</ref> hope for justice, and belief in one's ability to reduce injustice.<ref>Mohiyeddini, C., & Montada, L. (1998). [https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-1-4757-6418-5_3 BJW and self-efficacy in coping with observed victimization]. In L. Montada, & M. Lerner (Eds.), ''Responses to victimizations and belief in the just world'' (pp. 43–53). New York: Plenum.</ref> Other work has focused on looking at the different domains in which the belief may function; individuals may have different just-world beliefs for the personal domain, the sociopolitical domain, the social domain, etc.<ref name="FurnhamProcterAIDS" /> An especially fruitful distinction is between the belief in a just world for the self (personal) and the belief in a just world for others (general). These distinct beliefs are differentially associated with [[Just-world hypothesis#Positive mental health effects|positive mental health]].<ref name="Lipkusetal" />
==Correlates== Researchers have used measures of [[belief]] in a just world to look at correlates of high and low levels of belief in a just world.
Limited studies have examined ideological correlates of the belief in a just world. These studies have found sociopolitical correlates of just-world beliefs, including [[right-wing authoritarianism]] and the [[protestant work ethic]].<ref>Lambert, A. J., Burroughs, T., & Nguyen, T. (1999). [https://sites.google.com/site/alambertpsychology/publications/Lambertetal-riskperception.pdf Perceptions of risk and the buffering hypothesis: The role of just world beliefs and right wing authoritarianism]. ''Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin'', 25(6), 643–656.</ref><ref>Furnham, A. & Procter, E. (1989). [https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1111/j.2044-8309.1989.tb00880.x Belief in a just world: review and critique of the individual difference literature]. ''British Journal of Social Psychology'', 28, 365–384.</ref> Studies have also found belief in a just world to be correlated with aspects of [[religiousness]].<ref>Begue, L. (2002). [https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0191886900002245 Beliefs in justice and faith in people: just world, religiosity and interpersonal trust]. ''Personality and Individual Differences'', 32(3), 375–382.</ref><ref>Kurst, J., Bjorck, J., & Tan, S. (2000). [http://psycnet.apa.org/record/2000-07654-003 Causal attributions for uncontrollable negative events]. ''Journal of Psychology and Christianity'', 19, 47–60.</ref>
Studies of demographic differences, including [[gender]] and [[Race (classification of humans)|racial]] differences, have not shown systematic differences, but do suggest racial differences, with blacks and African Americans having the lowest levels of belief in a just world.<ref>Calhoun, L., & Cann, A. (1994). [https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/00224545.1994.9923011 Differences in assumptions about a just world: ethnicity and point of view]. ''Journal of Social Psychology'', 134, 765–770.</ref><ref>Hunt, M. (2000). [https://www.jstor.org/stable/42864385 Status, religion, and the ''belief in a just world'': comparing African Americans, Latinos, and Whites]. ''Social Science Quarterly'', 81, 325–343.</ref>
The development of measures of just-world beliefs has also allowed researchers to assess cross-cultural differences in just-world beliefs. Much research conducted shows that beliefs in a just world are evident cross-culturally. One study tested beliefs in a just world of students in 12 countries. This study found that in countries where the majority of inhabitants are powerless, belief in a just world tends to be weaker than in other countries.<ref>Furnham, A. (1993). [https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/00224545.1993.9712149 Just world beliefs in twelve societies]. ''Journal of Social Psychology'', 133, 317–329.</ref> This supports the theory of the just-world hypothesis because the powerless have had more personal and societal experiences that provided evidence that the world is not just and predictable.<ref>Furnham, A. (1992). Relationship knowledge and attitudes towards AIDS. ''Psychological Reports'', 71, 1149–1150.</ref>{{Clarify|reason=I assume you mean to say 'neither just nor predictable.'|date=February 2014}}
Belief in unjust world has been linked to increased self-handicapping, criminality, defensive coping, anger and perceived future risk. It may also serve as ego-protective belief for certain individuals by justifying maladaptive behavior.<ref name="Furnham2003Decade" /><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Lench|first1=Chang|title=Belief in an Unjust World: When Beliefs in a Just World Fail|journal=Journal of Personality Assessment|date=2007|volume=89|issue=2|pages=126–135|doi=10.1080/00223890701468477|pmid=17764390}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Dolinski|first1=Dariusz|title=The belief in an unjust world: An egotistic delusion|journal=Social Justice Research|date=1996|volume=9|issue=3|pages=213–221|doi=10.1007/BF02197248}}</ref>
==Current research==
===Positive mental health effects=== Although much of the initial work on belief in a just world focused on its negative social effects, other research suggests that belief in a just world is good, and even necessary, for [[mental health]].<ref>Dalbert, C. (2001). ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=sbKCnhCPaSgC&pg=PR3#v=onepage&q=%22The%20justice%20motive%20as%20a%20personal%20resource%3A%20dealing%20with%20challenges%20and%20critical%20life%20events%22 The justice motive as a personal resource: dealing with challenges and critical life events].'' New York: Plenum.</ref> Belief in a just world is associated with greater [[life satisfaction]] and well-being and less depressive affect.<ref name="Lipkusetal">Lipkus, I. M., Dalbert, C., & Siegler, I. C. (1996). [http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/abs/10.1177/0146167296227002 The Importance of Distinguishing the Belief in a Just World for Self Versus for Others: Implications for Psychological Well-Being]. ''Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin'', 22(7), 666–677.</ref><ref>Ritter, C., Benson, D. E., & Snyder, C. (1990). [http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/abs/10.2307/1389045 Belief in a just world and depression]. ''Sociological Perspective'', 25, 235–252.</ref> Researchers are actively exploring the reasons why the belief in a just world might have this relationship to mental health; it has been suggested that such beliefs could be a personal resource or [[coping (psychology)|coping strategy]] that buffers [[Stress (psychological)|stress]] associated with daily life and with [[psychological trauma|traumatic events]].<ref name = "HaferinMontadaLerner">Hafer, C., & Olson, J. (1998). Individual differences in beliefs in a just world and responses to personal misfortune. In L. Montada, & M. Lerner (Eds.), ''Responses to victimizations and belief in the just world'' (pp. 65–86). New York: Plenum.</ref> This hypothesis suggests that belief in a just world can be understood as a [[positive illusion]].<ref>Taylor, S.E., & Brown, J. (1988). [https://pdfs.semanticscholar.org/16c6/b13d227783a3466d7a0903d9ebb111904502.pdf Illusion and well-being: A social psychological perspective on mental health]. ''Psychological Bulletin'', 103, 193–210.</ref>
Some studies also show that beliefs in a just world are correlated with internal [[locus of control]].<ref name="RubinPeplau1975" /> Strong belief in a just world is associated with greater acceptance of and less dissatisfaction with negative events in one's life.<ref name = "HaferinMontadaLerner" /> This may be one way in which belief in a just world affects mental health. Others have suggested that this relationship holds only for beliefs in a just world for oneself. Beliefs in a just world for others are related instead to the negative social phenomena of victim blaming and victim derogation observed in other studies.<ref>Sutton, R., & Douglas, K. (2005). [https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S019188690500070X Justice for all, or just for me? More evidence of the importance of the self-other distinction in just-world beliefs]. ''Personality and Individual Differences'', 39(3), 637–645.</ref>
===International research=== More than 40 years after Lerner's seminal work on belief in a just world, researchers continue to study the phenomenon. Work continues primarily in the United States, Europe, Australia, and Asia.<ref name="MaesEightStages" /> Researchers in Germany have contributed disproportionately to recent research.<ref name="MontadaLernerPreface" /> Their work resulted in a volume edited by Lerner and German researcher Leo Montada titled ''Responses to Victimizations and Belief in a Just World''.<ref>Montada, L. & Lerner, M. (Eds.) (1998) ''Responses to victimizations and belief in the just world''. New York: Plenum.</ref>
==See also== {{columns-list|colwidth=30em| *"[[Best of all possible worlds]]" **[[Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz]] **''[[Candide]]'' **[[Problem of evil]] *[[Denial]] *[[Fundamental attribution error]] *[[Hindsight bias]] *{{sectionlink|Karma|Comparable concepts}} *[[Mean world syndrome]] *[[Moral panic]] *[[Natural disasters as divine retribution]] *[[System justification]] *[[Theodicy]] *[[Victim blaming]] }}
==References== {{reflist|colwidth=33em}}
==Further reading== *{{cite journal |last=Hafer |first=C. L. |last2=Bègue |year=2005 |url=http://www.brocku.ca/psychology/people/Hafer_Begue_05.pdf |title=Experimental research on just-world theory: problems, developments, and future challenges |journal=Psychological Bulletin |volume=131 |issue=1 |pages=128–167 |doi=10.1037/0033-2909.131.1.128 |pmid=15631556 |citeseerx=10.1.1.524.1990 }} *{{cite book|doi=10.1016/bs.aesp.2014.09.001|chapter=The Why and How of Defending Belief in a Just World|volume=51|pages=41–96|title=Advances in Experimental Social Psychology|year=2015|last1=Hafer|first1=Carolyn L.|last2=Rubel|first2=Alicia N.|isbn=9780128022740}} *{{cite book |last=Lerner |first=Melvin J. |year=1980 |title=The Belief in a Just World: A Fundamental Delusion |series=Perspectives in Social Psychology |location=New York |publisher=Plenum Press |isbn=978-0-306-40495-5 }} *{{cite book |last=Montada |first=Leo |last2=Lerner |first2=Melvin J. |year=1998 |title=Responses to Victimizations and Belief in a Just World |series=Critical Issues in Social Justice |location= |publisher= |isbn=978-0-306-46030-2 |doi=10.1007/978-1-4757-6418-5}} *{{cite journal|last=Rubin |first=Z. |last2=Peplau |first2=L. A. |year=1975 |url=http://www.peplaulab.ucla.edu/Publications_files/Rubin%20%26%20Peplau%201975s.pdf |title=Who believes in a just world? |journal=Journal of Social Issues |volume=31 |issue=3 |pages=65–90 |doi=10.1111/j.1540-4560.1975.tb00997.x |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720073011/http://www.peplaulab.ucla.edu/Publications_files/Rubin%20%26%20Peplau%201975s.pdf |archivedate=2011-07-20 |df= }} Reprinted (1977) in Reflections, XII(1), 1–26. *{{cite journal|last=Rubin |first=Z. |last2=Peplau |first2=L. A. |year=1973 |title=Belief in a just world and reactions to another's lot: A study of participants in the national draft lottery |journal=Journal of Social Issues |volume=29 |issue=4 |pages=73–94 |doi=10.1111/j.1540-4560.1973.tb00104.x |url=http://www.peplaulab.ucla.edu/Publications_files/Rubin_Peplau_73.pdf |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720073030/http://www.peplaulab.ucla.edu/Publications_files/Rubin_Peplau_73.pdf |archivedate=July 20, 2011 }}
==External links== *[http://www.units.muohio.edu/psybersite/justworld/index.shtml The Just World Hypothesis] *[http://www.scu.edu/ethics/publications/iie/v3n2/justworld.html Issues in Ethics: The Just World Theory]

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contribs/2607:FEA8:84A0:A0D:340E:B8C1:3D1E:E569|2607:FEA8:84A0:A0D:340E:B8C1:3D1E:E569]] ([[User talk:2607:FEA8:84A0:A0D:340E:B8C1:3D1E:E569|talk]]) to last version by Srich32977
revision.text:
To '''kick the bucket''' is an [[English language|English]] [[idiom]], considered a [[euphemistic]], informal, or [[slang]] term meaning 'to die'.<ref>Oxford Advanced Dictionary of Current English, 4th Ed. (1989)</ref> Its origin remains unclear, though there have been several theories.
==Origin theories== A common theory is that the idiom refers to hanging, either as a method of execution or suicide. However, there is no evidence to support this. Its earliest appearance is in the ''[[Dictionary of the Vulgar Tongue]]'' (1785), where it is defined as 'to die'.<ref name="phrase"/> In [[John Badcock (writer)|John Badcock]]'s slang dictionary of 1823, the explanation is given that "One Bolsover having hung himself from a beam while standing on a pail, or bucket, kicked this vessel away in order to pry into futurity and it was all UP with him from that moment: ''Finis''".<ref>''Slang: a dictionary of the turf, the ring, the chase, the pit, of bon-ton, and the varieties of life'', London 1823, [https://books.google.com/books?id=MbRMAAAAYAAJ&lpg=PA18&ots=nIFfqQEQRC&dq=%22Bolsover%2C%20having%20hung%20himself%22&pg=PA18#v=onepage&q=%22Bolsover,%20having%20hung%20himself%22&f=false p. 18]</ref>
The theory favoured by the [[Oxford English Dictionary|OED]] relates to the alternative definition of a bucket as a beam or yoke that can be used to hang or carry things on.<ref name="phrase"/><ref name=OED>"Bucket." ''The Oxford English Dictionary''. 2nd ed. 1989.</ref> The "bucket" may refer to the beam on which [[Animal slaughter|slaughtered]] [[pigs]] are suspended. The animals may struggle on the bucket, hence the expression.<ref name="phrase"/> The word "bucket" still can be used today to refer to such a beam in the [[Norfolk dialect]].<ref name="oxford">''Oxford Dictionary of Idioms'', p. 159</ref> It is thought that this definition came from the [[French language|French]] word ''[[trébuchet]]'' or ''buque'', meaning balance.<ref name="phrase">[http://www.phrases.org.uk/meanings/218800.html The Phrase Finder]</ref><ref name=OED/> [[William Shakespeare]] used the word in this sense in his play [[Henry IV Part II]] where he says:<ref name="phrase"/> {{quote|Swifter than he that [[wikt:gibbet#Verb|gibbet]]s on the Brewers Bucket.|William Shakespeare|Henry IV Part II}}
A third theory suggests that the origin of the phrase comes from the Catholic custom of holy-water buckets:<ref>"Relics of Popery", Catholic Truth Society London</ref> {{Quote|After death, when a body had been laid out ... the holy-water bucket was brought from the church and put at the feet of the corpse. When friends came to pray... they would sprinkle the body with holy water ... it is easy to see how such a saying as "kicking the bucket " came about. Many other explanations of this saying have been given by persons who are unacquainted with Catholic custom|The Right Reverend Abbot Horne|''Relics of Popery''}} Alternatively, in the moment of death a person stretches his legs (in Spanish ''Estirar la pata'' means 'to die') and so might kick the bucket placed there.
Yet another theory seeks to extend the saying beyond its earliest use in the 16th century with reference to the Latin proverb ''Capra Scyria'', the goat that is said to kick over the pail after being milked (920 in Erasmus' [[Adagia]]). Thus a promising beginning is followed by a bad ending or, as [[Andrea Alciato]] phrased it in the Latin poem accompanying the drawing in his ''Emblemata'' (1524), 'Because you have spoilt your fine beginnings with a shameful end and turned your service into harm, you have done what the she-goat does when she kicks the bucket that holds her milk and with her hoof squanders her own riches'.<ref>[http://www.emblems.arts.gla.ac.uk/french/emblem.php?id=FALc140 Emblem 160]</ref> Here it is the death of one's reputation that is in question.
==American variations== At one time the American and [[British West Indies|Caribbean]] expression 'kickeraboo' used to be explained as a deformed version of 'kick the bucket'.<ref>John Camden Hotton, The Slang Dictionary, London 1865, [https://books.google.com/books?id=0k1dv1hVdSoC&lpg=PA164&ots=wQWGNw77K1&dq=%22kickeraboo%22%20Slang%20Dictionary&pg=PA164#v=onepage&q=%22kickeraboo%22%20Slang%20Dictionary&f=false pp. 164–65]</ref> The expression occurs as the title of a mid-19th century American minstrel ballad with the ending 'Massa Death bring one bag and we Kickeraboo'.<ref>Lubrano broadside ballad collection [http://collections.mun.ca/cdm4/item_viewer.php?CISOROOT=/broadside&CISOPTR=389&CISOBOX=1&REC=8 68]</ref> However, it is now thought that it may have derived from a native word in one of the West African creoles. The expression 'kek(e)rebu' is first recorded in 1721 with the meaning 'to die' in the [[Krio language]] of [[Sierra Leone]].<ref>On the Anglophone Creole item ''kekrebu'', American English 30/3, 1985, [https://www.jstor.org/discover/10.2307/454900?uid=3738032&uid=2129&uid=2&uid=70&uid=4&sid=21101007321433 pp. 281–83]</ref> Earlier still 'Kickativoo' is recorded in [[Ghana]] (then known as the Gold or Slave Coast). In 1680 it referred to the capsizing of a canoe but also had the meaning 'to die'.<ref>Magnus Huber, Ghanaian Pidgin English in Its West African Context, John Benjamins Publishing Co. 1999, [https://books.google.com/books?id=U0NFweXVDOgC&lpg=PA24&ots=q3lOMlwx0M&dq=kickeraboo&pg=PA24#v=onepage&q=kickeraboo&f=false p. 24]</ref>
Whatever [[African American]] usage might have been in the 19th century, by the 20th century they were using the idiom 'kick the bucket'. It occurs in the [[jazz]] classic ''Old Man Mose'', recorded by [[Louis Armstrong]] in the US in 1935, and in the West Indies it figured in the title of the [[reggae]] hit “Long Shot kick de bucket”, recorded by [[The Pioneers (band)|The Pioneers]] in 1969. In the case of the latter, the song refers to the death of a horse.
In [[North America]], a variation of the idiom is 'kick off'.<ref>Cambridge Advanced Learner's Dictionary, p. 787</ref> A related phrase is to "hand in one's dinner pail", a bucket that contains a [[Laborer|worker]]'s [[dinner]].<ref name=oxford/> Another variation, '[[Wish list|bucket list]]', or a list of things to do before one dies, is derived from "to kick the bucket".<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/bucket%20list | title=Definition of bucket list | publisher=Merriam-Webster | accessdate=21 March 2014}}</ref>
==See also== * [[List of expressions related to death]]
==References== {{wiktionary}} {{reflist}}
[[Category:English phrases]] [[Category:English-language idioms]] [[Category:Cultural aspects of death]] [[Category:Euphemisms]]

page.title: List of biotech and pharmaceutical companies in the New York metropolitan area

revision.comment: rmv spc
revision.text:
'''Biotech and pharmaceutical companies in the New York metropolitan area''' represent a significant and growing economic component of the [[New York metropolitan area]],<ref>[http://techventures.columbia.edu/news-and-events/latest-news/nyc%E2%80%99s-biotech-startup-ecosystem] Accessed December 23, 2016.</ref><ref name = "Noto_2015">{{cite web | url = http://www.bizjournals.com/newyork/news/2015/11/06/sector-spotlight-how-biotech-in-n-y-c-holds-up.html | title = Sector spotlight: How biotech in N.Y.C. holds up compared to other cities | quote = ''However, [NYC biotech is] considered second tier when held up against other cities.'' | work = New York Business Journal | first = Anthony | last= Noto | name-list-format = vanc | date = November 6, 2015|accessdate=January 8, 2016}}</ref> the most populous [[List of Combined Statistical Areas|combined statistical area]] in the United States<ref name=CombinedEst>{{cite web|url=http://factfinder.census.gov/bkmk/table/1.0/en/PEP/2015/GCTPEPANNR.US41PR|title=Annual Estimates of the Resident Population: April 1, 2010 to July 1, 2015 – Combined Statistical Area; and for Puerto Rico – 2015 Population Estimates|publisher=U.S. Census Bureau|accessdate=November 10, 2016}}</ref> and one of the most populous [[megacity|megacities]] in the world.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mongabay.com/cities_urban_01.htm |title=World's Largest Urban Areas [Ranked by Urban Area Population] |publisher=Rhett Butler |year=2003–2006 |accessdate=November 10, 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=http://arquivo.pt/wayback/20091009143739/http://www.mongabay.com/cities_urban_01.htm |archivedate=October 9, 2009 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.worldatlas.com/citypops.htm |title=Largest Cities of the World – (by metro population) |publisher=Woolwine-Moen Group d/b/a Graphic Maps |accessdate=November 10, 2016}}</ref>
The biotechnology sector is growing in the New York City area, based upon the region's strength in academic scientific [[research]] and public and commercial financial support. By mid-2014, Accelerator, a biotech [[investment]] firm, had raised more than US$30 million from [[investor]]s, including [[Eli Lilly and Company]], [[Pfizer]], and [[Johnson & Johnson]], for initial funding to create biotechnology [[startup company|startups]] at the Alexandria Center for Life Science, which encompasses more than {{convert|700,000|sqft|m2}} on [[29th Street (Manhattan)|East 29th Street]] and promotes collaboration among scientists and entrepreneurs at the center and with nearby academic, medical, and research institutions. The [[New York City Economic Development Corporation]]'s Early Stage Life Sciences Funding Initiative and venture capital partners, including [[Celgene]], [[General Electric]] Ventures, and Eli Lilly, committed a minimum of US$100 million to help launch 15 to 20 ventures in [[life sciences]] and biotechnology in 2014,<ref name=Alexandria2014>{{cite news | last = Morris | first = Keiko | name-list-format = vanc | url = https://online.wsj.com/articles/wanted-biotech-startups-in-new-york-city-1406603189 | title=Wanted: Biotech Startups in New York City: The Alexandria Center for Life Science Looks to Expand | newspaper = The Wall Street Journal | date = 28 July 2014 | accessdate = 1 August 2014 }}</ref> and in January 2018, the City of New York itself committed up to US$100 million into the venture.<ref name=Alexandria2018>{{cite web|url=https://cen.acs.org/articles/96/i10/New-York-City-biotech-scene.html|title=New York City biotech scene gains more traction|author=Ryan Cross|publisher=C&EN Chemical and Engineering News|date=March 5, 2018|accessdate=April 25, 2018}}</ref>
In December 2014, the State of [[New York (state)|New York]] announced a US$50 million venture-capital fund to encourage enterprises working in biotechnology and [[Materials science|advanced materials]]; according to Governor [[Andrew Cuomo]], the [[seed money]] would facilitate entrepreneurs in bringing their research into the marketplace.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2014-12-12/new-york-state-will-start-50-million-venture-capital-fund.html | title = New York State Will Start $50 Million Venture-Capital Fund | first= Freeman | last = Klopott | name-list-format = vanc | publisher = Bloomberg L.P | date = 12 December 2014 | accessdate = 12 December 2014 }}</ref>
Below is a list of notable New York metropolitan area [[biotechnology]] and [[pharmaceutical industry|pharmaceutical corporations]], including companies with either global or U.S. [[headquarters]] in the metropolitan region encompassing and surrounding [[New York City]].

revision.text:
{{Infobox cricketer | name = Loretta Bayliss | female = true | country = New Zealand | fullname = Loretta Irene Bayliss | birth_date = 1939 | birth_place = [[Christchurch]], New Zealand | death_date = 30 June 1966 (aged 26–27) | death_place = Christchurch, New Zealand | batting = Left-handed | bowling = Left-arm fast-medium
| international = true | onetest = true | testdebutdate = 17 March | testdebutyear = 1961 | testdebutagainst = Australia
| club1 = [[Canterbury Magicians|Canterbury]] | year1 =
| columns = 1 | column1 = [[Women's Test cricket|Test]] | matches1 = 1 | runs1 = – | bat avg1 = – | 100s/50s1 = –/– | top score1 = – | deliveries1 = 198 | wickets1 = 5 | bowl avg1 = 14.00 | fivefor1 = 1 | tenfor1 = 0 | best bowling1 = 5/28 | catches/stumpings1 = 0/0
| date = 18 February | year = 2013 | source = https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Players/17/17233/17233.html CricketArchive }} '''Loretta Irene Bayliss''' (1939 – 30 June 1966) was a [[cricket]]er who played one [[Women's Test cricket|women's Test match]] for [[New Zealand national women's cricket team|New Zealand]] in 1961. A left-handed batsman and left-arm fast-medium pace bowler,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Players/17/17233/17233.html |title=Player Profile: Loretta Bayliss |publisher=CricketArchive |accessdate=18 February 2013}}</ref> she is one of thirteen cricketers to have taken a [[Glossary of cricket terms#F|five-wicket haul]] on their debut in women's Test cricket. On her only international appearance, she claimed five wickets for the concession of 28 runs in the second innings against [[Australia women's cricket team|Australia]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/engine/match/67429.html |title=Only Test: New Zealand Women v Australia Women at Dunedin, Mar 17–19, 1961 |publisher=ESPNcricinfo |accessdate=18 February 2013}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Bayliss, Loretta}} [[Category:1939 births]] [[Category:1966 deaths]] [[Category:New Zealand women cricketers]] [[Category:New Zealand women Test cricketers]] [[Category:Cricketers from Christchurch]] [[Category:Date of birth missing]] [[Category:Canterbury Magicians cricketers]] {{NewZealand-cricket-bio-1930s-stub}}

{{ infobox nobility | name = Magnus II | title = [[Duke of Brunswick-Lüneburg]] | image = File:Magnustorquatus.jpg | caption = | noble family= [[House of Guelph]] | father = [[Magnus the Pious, Duke of Brunswick-Lüneburg]] | mother = [[Sophia_of_Brandenburg-Stendal|Sophie of Brandenburg-Stendal]] | spouse = Catherine of Anhalt-Bernburg | issue = [[Catherine Elisabeth of Brunswick-Lüneburg|Catherine Elizabeth]]
[[Frederick I, Duke of Brunswick-Lüneburg|Frederick I]]
[[Bernard I, Duke of Brunswick-Lüneburg|Bernard I]]
Otto
[[Henry the Mild, Duke of Brunswick-Lüneburg|Henry the Mild]]
Agnes I
Helen
Elizabeth
[[Agnes of Brunswick-Lüneburg|Agnes II]] | birth_date = 1324 | birth_place = | death_date = 1373 | death_place = }} '''Magnus''' (1324–1373), called '''Magnus with the Necklace''' ('''{{lang-lat|Magnus Torquatus}}''') or '''Magnus II''', was Duke of Brunswick-Lüneburg, ruling the [[Brunswick-Lüneburg]] principalities of [[Brunswick-Wolfenbüttel|Wolfenbüttel]] (colloquially also called Brunswick) and, temporarily, [[Lüneburg-Celle|Lüneburg]]. ==Biography== Magnus was the son of [[Magnus the Pious, Duke of Brunswick-Lüneburg|Magnus the Pious, Duke of Brunswick-Lüneburg (Wolfenbüttel)]]. In 1362 Magnus and his brother Louis I, Duke of Brunswick-Lüneburg helped their brother Prince-Archbishop [[Albert of Brunswick and Lunenburg-Wolfenbüttel|Albert II]] of [[Prince-Archbishopric of Bremen|Bremen]] to assert himself against the incumbent [[diocesan administrator]] Morris of Oldenburg, who claimed the [[Episcopal see|see]] for himself. Magnus, Louis and the latter's father-in-law [[William II, Duke of Brunswick-Lüneburg|William II, Duke of Brunswick-Lüneburg (Celle)]], and their troops beleaguered Morris in the [[Vörde Castle|prince-archiepiscopal castle]] in [[Bremervörde|Vörde]] and forced him to sign his resignation. After the death of his brother Louis in 1367, Magnus became the designated heir of both ducal principalities, Wolfenbüttel and [[Lüneburg-Celle|Celle]] (colloquially also Lüneburg). When both his father and William II, who ruled over Celle, died in 1369, Magnus gained both ducal principalities. But already in 1370, he lost Celle to the [[Ascanian]] dukes of [[Saxe-Wittenberg]] ([[Albert of Saxe-Wittenberg, Duke of Lüneburg|Albert]] and his uncle [[Wenceslas I, Duke of Saxe-Wittenberg|Wenceslas, Elector of Saxe-Wittemberg]]), who had been given the principality by [[Charles IV, Holy Roman Emperor]], who had also banned Magnus. Several cities, including [[Lüneburg|Lüneburg (Lunenburg)]], [[Uelzen]], and [[Hanover]] switched allegiance to the Ascanians; Magnus managed to keep the City of [[Brunswick (city)|Braunschweig (Brunswick)]] among his allies only with difficulties. The [[Lüneburg War of Succession]] continued for several years after Magnus died in the Battle of Leveste (a part of today's [[Gehrden]]), near the [[Deister]], on 25 July 1373. ==Family== Magnus married Catherine, daughter of [[Bernhard III, Prince of Anhalt-Bernburg]], who married Magnus' enemy, Albert, Duke of Saxe-Wittenberg, after his death. They had the following children: *[[Catherine Elisabeth of Brunswick-Lüneburg|Catherine Elizabeth]] married [[Gerhard VI, Count of Holstein-Rendsburg|Gerhard II/VI]], Duke of Schleswig/Count of Holstein-Rendsburg (ca. 1367 – 4 August 1404) *[[Frederick I, Duke of Brunswick-Lüneburg]] (1357–1400), married [[Anna of Saxe-Wittenberg]] (died 1440) *[[Bernard I, Duke of Brunswick-Lüneburg]] (died 1434), married Margaret of Saxony (before 1370 – 1418) *Otto, Archbishop of [[Bremen]] (ca. 1364–1406) *[[Henry the Mild, Duke of Brunswick-Lüneburg]] (died 1416) *Agnes I (died 1410), married [[Albert I, Duke of Brunswick-Grubenhagen|Albert I, Duke of Brunswick-Lüneburg]] (1339–1383) *Helen, married [[Eric I, Count of Hoya]] *Elizabeth (died 1420), married Maurice IV, Count of Oldenburg (1380–1420) *[[Agnes of Brunswick-Lüneburg|Agnes II]] (before 1356 – ca. 1416), married first Busso IV, Count of Mansfeld, then [[Bogislaw VI, Duke of Pomerania]], and finally King [[Albert of Sweden]] *Sophie (1358–by 28 May 1416), married Duke [[Eric IV of Saxe-Lauenburg|Eric IV]] of [[Saxe-Lauenburg]] on 8 April 1373. *Maud (1370–??), married Otto III, Count of Hoya (died 1428) ==Ancestry== {{ahnentafel |collapsed=yes |align=center |boxstyle_1=background-color: #fcc; |boxstyle_2=background-color: #fb9; |boxstyle_3=background-color: #ffc; |boxstyle_4=background-color: #bfc; |boxstyle_5=background-color: #9fe; |1= 1. '''Magnus II, Duke of Brunswick-Lüneburg''' |2= 2. [[Magnus the Pious, Duke of Brunswick-Lüneburg]] |3= 3. Sophie of Brandenburg-Stendal |4= 4. [[Albert the Fat, Duke of Brunswick-Lüneburg]] |5= 5. [[Rixa of Werle|Rixa of Mecklenburg-Werle]] |6= 6. [[Henry I, Margrave of Brandenburg-Stendal]] |7= 7. Agnes of Bavaria |8= 8. [[Albert I, Duke of Brunswick-Lüneburg]] |9= 9. Adelheid of Montferrat |10= 10. [[Henry I, Prince of Mecklenburg-Güstrow]] |11= 11. [[Rikissa Birgersdotter]] |12= 12. [[John I, Margrave of Brandenburg]] |13= 13. Jutta of Saxony |14= 14. [[Louis II, Duke of Bavaria]] |15= 15. [[Matilda of Habsburg]] |16= 16. [[Otto I, Duke of Brunswick-Lüneburg]] |17= 17. [[Matilda of Brandenburg, Duchess of Brunswick-Lüneburg|Matilda of Brandenburg]] |18= 18. [[Boniface II, Marquess of Montferrat]] |19= 19. Margaret of Savoy |20= 20. [[Nicholas I of Werle|Nicholas I, Prince of Mecklenburg-Werle]] |21= 21. Jutta of Anhalt |22= 22. [[Birger Jarl]] |23= 23. [[Ingeborg Eriksdotter of Sweden]] |24= 24.
